name: Graph Minor Theorem
rephrased: The Graph Minors Theorem, also known as the Robertsonâ€“Seymour theorem, states that the family of all finite graphs, when partially ordered by the "minor" relationship, forms a well-quasi-ordering. This means any class of graphs closed under taking minors can be characterized by a finite set of forbidden minors, and it implies that for any fixed graph H, we can check in polynomial time if H is a minor of a given graph G.
implication form: The implication form of the graph minor theorem states that for any finite graph \(H\), there is a polynomial-time algorithm to test if a graph \(G\) contains \(H\) as a minor. A consequence of this is that any graph property closed under taking minors (deletion and contraction) can be recognized in polynomial time. For example, a property like embeddability in a particular surface is closed under these operations, and thus the theorem implies it can be tested efficiently for any given surface.
terms: minor (a graph obtained by deleting edges/vertices and contracting edges)
well-quasi-ordering (the minor relation is a well-quasi-order)
forbidden minors (a finite set of graphs that characterize a minor-closed property)
graph structure theorem (which describes the structure of graphs with a given excluded minor)
topological minors (a variation of minors that involves subdivisions)
related_conjectures: Hadwiger's conjecture, which links a graph's chromatic number to its possible clique minors
Wagner's conjecture, which states that any infinite set of graphs must contain a minor-containment relationship between two members
